title: 107_hr794
content: The Act titled "Energy Security for American Consumers Act of 2001" extends the credit for producing fuel from a nonconventional source. The "Energy Security for American Consumers Act of 2001" extends the credit for producing fuel from a nonconventional source, allowing for wells drilled or facilities placed in service between December 30, 2000, and January 1, 2012, to qualify for the credit. The Energy Security for American Consumers Act of 2001 extends the credit for producing fuel from a nonconventional source to wells drilled or facilities placed in service before January 1, 2012. The credit amount is reduced by 20 percent per year starting in 2010. The Energy Security for American Consumers Act of 2001 extends the credit for producing fuel from a nonconventional source to wells drilled or facilities placed in service before January 1, 2012. The applicable amount for the credit is determined according to a specific table. The Energy Security for American Consumers Act of 2001 extends the credit for producing fuel from a nonconventional source to wells drilled or facilities placed in service before January 1, 2012. The applicable amount for the credit varies from $3.00 in 2002-2011 to $0.00 in 2016 and thereafter. The credit is allowed against both regular tax and alternative minimum tax. The Energy Security for American Consumers Act of 2001 extends the credit for producing fuel from a nonconventional source to wells drilled or facilities placed in service before January 1, 2012. The credit amount varies annually and can be used against regular tax and alternative minimum tax. Subsection (c) of section 29 of the Code is amended to include heavy oil as a qualified fuel. The Energy Security for American Consumers Act of 2001 extends the credit for producing fuel from a nonconventional source to wells drilled or facilities placed in service before January 1, 2012. The amendment includes heavy oil as a qualified fuel, subject to specific conditions. The Energy Security for American Consumers Act of 2001 extends the credit for producing fuel from a nonconventional source to facilities placed in service before July 1, 1998, under a binding contract before January 1, 1997. The amendments made by this Act apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
